awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: RADAR: Real-time Advanced Detection and Attack Reconstruction
awd_abstract_narration:
There has been a rapid escalation of targeted cyber-attacks, called Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs), on high-profile enterprises. These skilled attacks routinely bypass widely deployed protection mechanisms. Existing second-line cyber defenses (e.g., intrusion detection systems) are helpful, but they often generate a flood of information that overwhelms cyber analysts. Moreover, analysts lack the tools to piece together attack fragments spanning multiple applications and/or hosts. This project will hence focus on developing the principles, techniques, and tools for accurate attack detection and real-time reconstruction of attacker activities across large enterprises.

Many intellectual challenges arise in APT campaign reconstruction, including: (a) developing a wide range of policy-based, anomaly-based and signature-based attack detectors, (b) connecting the dots in the presence of unreliable detectors, (c) scaling to large enterprise networks, and (d) resisting adversarial manipulation. To overcome these challenges, this project will explore several novel directions, including (i) domain-specific languages for cyber attack detection and forensics, (ii) novel detection techniques that leverage natural language descriptions of recent attacks, (iii) alternative dependence propagation semantics that mitigate dependence explosion, and (iv) mapping attack steps to the high-level objectives ("kill-chain") of APT actors.

Cyber technologies are inextricably woven into the fabric of today's society. Repeated cyber attacks undermine the society's trust in this fabric. Even in purely economic terms, worldwide cybercrime led to $600 billion in losses in 2017 (Source: McAfee). This project will help arrest these downward trends. It will also educate graduate, undergraduate and K-12 students through cybersecurity coursework, research, and outreach activities. Enhanced participation of women and minorities will be targeted through alliances with partners, including the National Center for Women & Information Technology, Governor's State University, and Chicago Public Schools. Project-related data, results, publications and tools will be made available through the web sites of the research laboratories collaborating on this project: http://seclab.cs.stonybrook.edu/ and http://sisl.lab.uic.edu/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of the RADAR project was to advance methods for advanced persistent threat detection and investigation, threat hunting, and response. The project made several advances to the state of the art.- Graph-based activity representation. One of the main challenges in detecting modern threats is the "needle-in-the-haystack" problem. Modern enterprises produce a very large amount of logs representing their activities. Advanced threat activities are often a miniscule part of such logs. To be able to identify malicious activities, we need a scalable and efficient log storage system. RADAR has developed a graph-based memory-efficient represntation to represent hundreds of millions to billions of activities inside an enterprise network on commodity laptops. [SLEUTH] - Real-time detection, investigation, and threat hunting methods. Leveraging the graph-based memory representation, RADAR creates multiple advanced methods to detect and investigate suspicious activities inside an enterprise network in real time. Some of these methods are aligned with MITRE's ATT&CK framework, which is a popular system to model known attack tactics, techniques, and procedures. RADAR has also developed additional methods that are able to identify unknown attacks, beyond the MITRE ATT&CK framework [SLEUTH, HOLMES, POIROT, OSTINATO, PROPATROL, IOT_ARTICLE, ENCYCLOPEDIA_ARTICLE]. [PATENT]- Threat intelligence extraction. An additional challenge in the area of threat detection and response is that of quickly identifying the type of threat, threat actors, and responding appropriately. Threat intelligence, or information about existing threats, is produced and shared in multiple different formats. RADAR built methods to extract actionable attacker behavior as a graph representation from natural language reports and automatically augmenting detection and attack investigation with threat intelligence [EXTRACTOR,CITAR,TIPCE].
The RADAR project was executed as a collaboration between members of the University of Illinois Chicago and Discovery Partners Institute and Stony Brook University (NSF Awards 1918667 and 1918542). In Chicago, the project trained 3 PhD students, 4 M.S. students, and 10+ undergraduate students. A PhD student who graduated from the project is now serving in the Google Cyber Response team, and the second one who graduates is now serving as a security researcher at Intel. Additional activities include a class developed for advanced persistent threats detection and response, as well as cybersecurity classes at Governors State University in Illinois. The project produced 10 papers and articles, and 1 patent, listed below. 


Published papers.CITAR: Cyberthreat Intelligence-driven Attack Reconstruction.SK. Ghosh, R Gjomemo, V.N. Venkatakrishnan. CODASPY 2025.
TIPCE: A Longitudinal Threat Intelligence Platform Comprehensiveness Analysis.K. Satvat, R. Gjomemo, VN. Venkatakrishnan. CODASPY 2024.
Detection and Threat-Hunting Approaches for Advanced Persistent Threats.SK. Ghosh, R Gjomemo. Encyclopedia of Cryptography, Security and Privacy.
Understanding indicators of compromise against cyber-attacks in industrial control systems: a security perspective.M. Asiri, N. Saxena, R. Gjomemo, P. Burnap. ACM transactions on cyber-physical systems 7 (2), 1-33.
Ostinato: Cross-host Attack Correlation Through Attack Activity Similarity Detection.SK. Ghosh, K. Satvat, R. Gjomemo, VN. Venkatakrishnan. CODASPY 2024.
Extractor: Extracting attack behavior from threat reports.K. Satvat, R. Gjomemo, VN. Venkatakrishnan. EuroS&P 2021.
Poirot: Aligning attack behavior with kernel audit records for cyber threat hunting.SM. Milajerdi, B. Eshete, R. Gjomemo, VN. Venkatakrishnan. CCS 2019.
Holmes: real-time apt detection through correlation of suspicious information flows.SM. Milajerdi, R. Gjomemo, B. Eshete, R. Sekar, VN. Venkatakrishnan. 2019 IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy (SP).

Patent.System and method associated with expedient detection and reconstruction of cyber events in a compact scenario representation using provenance tags and customizable policy. R. Sekar, J. Wang, MN. Hossain, SM. Milajerdi, B. Eshete, R. Gjomemo, VN. Venkatakrishnan, S. Stoller.US Patent 11,601,442


Last Modified: 02/04/2025
Modified by: Venkat Venkatakrishnan
